RECORD.TITLE: Richter The Enigma
Buy a Band No. 17: featuring 'Troika' from Lieutenant Kijé by S. Prokofiev
Russia's War: blood upon the snow
RECORD.NOTES: Video Tape x 5. 10 episodes in total. Episode 1: The Darkness Descends: Lenin's legacy - Stalin's rise to power; 2: The Hour Before Midnight: the dark days leading to war; 3: The Goths Ride East: Barbarossa: Nazi invasion of Russia; 4: Between Life and Death: the tragic seige of Leningrad; 5: The Fight from Within: Minsk ghetto and partisan movement; 6: The Cauldron Boils: Stalingrad fights for survival; 7: The Citadel: the great Kursk tank battle; 8: The False Dawn: the end is near - Poland is sacrificed; 9: The Fall of the Swastika: the death of Hitler - victory at last; 10: The Cult of Personality: the final days of Stalin

RECORD.NOTES: Copied from video 40 Contents: 1. Gymnastics Parade. July 1939, Red Square, Moscow 2. Section on Eisenstein. Shows plans and drawings for Ivan Grozny and a scene with Prokofiev at the piano 3. Persimfans, 1927, with Prokofiev playing (silent) 4. Prize giving ceremony with Prokofiev, Khachaturian, Shebalin etc. (silent) 5. Prokofiev at his dacha in 1946. Plays an extract from the Waltz Suite and is then interviewed (with sound) 6. About the Association of Soviet Composers with an exhibition on Prokofiev. Shows extracts from the 1946 film 7. Repeat of the 1946 film with interview

RECORD.TITLE: Lermontov
RECORD.NOTES: Copied from Video 42 06/03/2007 Albert Gendelshtein’s film is a portrait of the great nineteenth century Russian writer and poet Mikhail Lermontov, the inheritor of Pushkin’s mantle, who, like his mentor, died in a duel at the age of twenty six. Lermontov’s affection for the serfs and peasantry, and his criticisms of the Tsar, endeared him to the post-revolutionary Soviet regime. Prokofiev was one of two composers for the film (the other being Venedict Pushkov). Featuring Prokofiev’s two pieces, Contradance and Mephisto Waltz.

RECORD.TITLE: Tonya: nashi devushki
RECORD.NOTES: Copied from Video 41 06/03/2007 Abram Room’s Tonya tells the heroic story of a telephone operator who sacrifices her life by drawing Soviet artillery fire onto the Nazi weapons that are stored near her office. Like Room’s earlier film A Severe Young Man, Tonya was banned by the Soviet authorities. Prokofiev wrote the score in August 1942.

Shows plans and drawings for Ivan Grozny and a scene with Prokofiev at the piano 10'59'': Persimfans, 1927 (soundless), with Prokofiev playing 12'27'': Prize giving ceremony with Prokofiev, Khachaturian, Shebalin etc. (soundless) 13'07'': Prokofiev at his dacha in 1946. Plays an extract from the Waltz Suite and is then interviewed (with sound) 15'36'': About the Association of Soviet Composers with an exhibition on Prokofiev. It shows extracts from the 1946 film. 16'46'': Repeat of the 1946 film with interview.

RECORD.TITLE: Tonya: nashi devushki
RECORD.NOTES: Abram Room’s Tonya tells the heroic story of a telephone operator who sacrifices her life by drawing Soviet artillery fire onto the Nazi weapons that are stored near her office. Like Room’s earlier film A Severe Young Man, Tonya was banned by the Soviet authorities. Prokofiev wrote the score in August 1942.

RECORD.TITLE: Lermontov
RECORD.NOTES: Albert Gendelshtein’s film is a portrait of the great nineteenth century Russian writer and poet Mikhail Lermontov, the inheritor of Pushkin’s mantle, who, like his mentor, died in a duel at the age of twenty six. Lermontov’s affection for the serfs and peasantry, and his criticisms of the Tsar, endeared him to the post-revolutionary Soviet regime. Prokofiev was one of two composers for the film (the other being Venedict Pushkov). Featuring Prokofiev’s two pieces, Contradance and Mephisto Waltz.

RECORD.TITLE: ALL THE RUSSIAS: a journey through Russia and her music. Programme 1 (The Little Birch Tree); Programme 2 (Holy Mother Russia)

SECONDARY_AUTHORS.SECONDARY_AUTHOR: Simon Broughton - director (programme 1); Peter West - director (programme 2)

RECORD.ABSTRACT: Programme 1: Russian have always espoused village life. Over the conturies, the traditions of folk culture have been an assertion of the Russian identity and the melodies of the countryside can be found everywhere in Russian classical music. Filmed largely in the remote countryside, this first programme is an evocation of Russia's rural heart and a search for the origins of the Russian folk-song that is at the core of all Russian music. Programme 2: Russia is at once dwevoutly Christian and deeply pagan. Both faith and magic were stuffed into the deep-freeze by the Soviets. What has emerged since the thaw is inspiring and alarming in equal measure. Filmed in Moscow, Kiev, Saint Petersburg and the holy sites of Sergevev Pasad and Bogolyubovo, during Easter festivities, Programme Two shows how the preoccupation with things spiritual is in all Russian music.
RECORD.NOTES: Broadcast on BBC 4. Series Producer: Dennis Marks. Series Consultant: Gerard McBurney. With Valery Gergiev and the Mariinsky Opera and Ballet Company

RECORD.TITLE: Choreography by Balanchine
RECORD.NOTES: Includes The Prodigal Son

RECORD.TITLE: ALL THE RUSSIAS: a journey through Russia and her music. Programme 3 (Devils)
RECORD.ABSTRACT: Programme 3: Russia's whole history has been marked by bloodshed and tyranny. No wonder then that the artistic representation of evil is more vivid inRussia than almost anywhere else in the world. Programme Three explores the pursuit of power and its consequences in Russian history and culture, demonstrating how the violence of Russian history is reflected in music that combines beauty and brutality.
RECORD.NOTES: Broadcast on BBC 4. Series Producer: Dennis Marks. Series Consultant: Gerard McBurney. With Valery Gergiev and the Mariinsky Opera and Ballet Company

RECORD.TITLE: Voina i Mir, opera v odinnadtsati kartinakh. Mirovaia prem'era [War and Peace, opera in eleven scenes. World premiere]
RECORD.NOTES: Not currently for public viewing due to intellectual property rights issues (Rita McAllister, 17/11/2010), therefore not currently on public [Aleph] catalogue. Rostov production of the original version of War and Peace, produced in collaboration with the Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama, and also performed in Glasgow and Edinburgh.

RECORD.TITLE: ALL THE RUSSIAS: a journey through Russia and her music. Programme 4 (Once Upon a Time); Programme 5 (Looking East, Looking West)

SECONDARY_AUTHORS.SECONDARY_AUTHOR: Barrie Gavin - director (Programme 4); Simon Broughton - director (Programme 5)

RECORD.ABSTRACT: Programme 4: The fourth programme looks at one of the archetypal forms of Russian culture, the fairy tale. An essential part of Russian childhood, these stories with their princesses, heroes and magical characters are also the inspiration of many of the great Russian ballets, operas, symphonic poems and piano works. Programme 5: Throughout Russian history there has been a love/hate relationship with her neighbours, oscillating between fear and loathing, envy and imitation. This final programme in the series travels from the edge of the one-time empire - from Georgia and the wild mountains of the Caucasus and the remote steppes of Uzbekistan to the heart of Russia - and reveals that the cultural and musical impact of these conflicts has been vast, colourful and searing. Gergiev concludes the series with an impassioned plea to preserve national identity in the face of invasion by Microsoft and Micky Mouse.
RECORD.NOTES: Broadcast on BBC 4. Series Producer: Dennis Marks. Series Consultant: Gerard McBurney. With Valery Gergiev and the Mariinsky Opera and Ballet Company

RECORD.NOTES: Valery Gergiev and Oleg Prokofiev in conversation about the 'Scythian Suite'. In Dutch

RECORD.TITLE: Composer Sergei Prokofiev
RECORD.ABSTRACT: DESCRIPTION: A biography covering his whole life from a Soviet perspective, omitting events embarrassing to the regime, in particular the banning of some works and the condemnation of his music in 1948. Includes extensive selections from his music in all genres performed by artists who knew the composer. DIRECTOR: Lidia Stepanova PRODUCER: Lidia Stepanova, Z. Grigorieva. CREDITS: Script: V. Komissarzhevsky. Chief consultants: Dmitri Kabalevsky, Ilya Nestyev. Consultants: V. Grigoriev, Mira Mendelson-Prokofieva, Boris Pokrovsky, G. Ansimov. Camera: Yu. Berenshtein. General Editor:V. Russo. Sound: K. Bek-Nazarov. Sets: P. Smirnov. Animated film: Yu. Merkulova. Composite photography: V. Sivkov. Editor: Z. Kochubei. [Original Russian narrator]: L. Khmara. Series Producer: B. Rodin. Orchestral conductors: Alexander Melik-Pashaev, Gennadi Rozhdestvensky, Georgii Zhemchuzhin, Mark Ermler. Ballet master: Kasian Goleizovsky. Performers: Galina Vishnevskaya (soprano), V. Vasiliev, Yevgeny Kibkalo (bass), Alexsei Krivchenko (bass), Vera Maretskaya (narrator in Peter and the Wolf), Lev Oborin (piano), David Oistrakh (violin), Mstislav Rostropovich (cello), Raissa Struchkova and Galina Ulanova (ballerinas), Artur Eizen (bass). SEGMENT 1: Credits over images of Gennadi Rozhdestvesky conducting the March from 'The Love of Three Oranges'. A book of Hans Christian Andersen's stories opens. An animated film accompanies an abbreviated version of Prokofiev's 'The Ugly Duckling'. The birth of the 'duckling' and his rejection by various animals. Winter comes and he is covered by snow. Spring. Birds sing and blossom blooms and the duckling, transformed into a swan, swims on a lake and flies with others into the sunset. Peter Konchalovsky's 1934 painting of Prokofiev. The writer Maxim Gorky said the song was autobiographical and though the music critic Boris Asafiev agreed, he said it hadn't turned out well because Prokofiev had not yet turned into a swan himself. SEGMENT 2: Sontsovka, the village where Prokofiev was born in April 1891. Piano music. Inside family house. Prokofiev began composing when he was five-and-a-half; his talent came from his mother playing piano while he was in the womb. Photograph of his mother, Maria. Prokofiev's memoirs about hearing her play a Chopin waltz when he was a child. Photograph of Prokofiev at the piano with the score of his first opera 'The Giant', written when he was nine. Piano music. His teachers included Reinhold Gliere and Sergei Taneyev. Prokofiev went to St Petersburg to enroll at the music conservatoire. Shots of St Petersburg: a canal; the Bronze Horseman; the sphinx by the River Neva; the Conservatoire. Photograph of teachers: Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov, Anatoli Liadov and Alexander Glazunov. Inside the conservatoire. Despite admiring Rimsky-Korsakov's music, Prokofiev tried to find his own voice. Piano music. Stills of Prokofiev and his friend Nikolai Miaskovsky in front of film of people waltzing. SEGMENT 3: Rich red sunset. 1913, Russia is about to enter World War One. The poet Alexander Blok wrote: 'The smell of fire, iron and blood was already in the air'. Recreated scenes of bourgeois life with popular brass band music. Recreation of the scandalous premiere of Prokofiev's Second Piano Concerto in Pavlovsk. The audience is bored or outraged; many leave. The narrator describes the music as a warning of bloodshed to come, which the audience takes as an insult and a challenge though young people understood. An unidentified poem is read about a pianist. Pages from the score of his graduation piece, the First Piano Concerto (on the soundtrack). Prokofiev was praised by the poet Vladimir Mayakovsky. Pages from his verse; the narrator quotes: 'Revolution in a crown of thorns will break forth in the year sixteen'. Though Mayakovsky erred by one year, Prokofiev was completely oblivious to the political events. Recreations of the Revolution while Prokofiev writes his Classical Symphony (the Gavotte on the soundtrack). Formal gardens and baroque palaces. SEGMENT 4: Recreations of revolutionary Petrograd. Prokofiev thinks music is irrelevant to the country yet his Classical Symphony was performed on 21 April 1918 (first movement on soundtrack). The music had a new kind of audience (soldiers march through the streets) and present was the first People's Commissar for Education, Anatoli Lunacharsky. Interiors of the concert hall. Beginning the most tangled part of his career, Prokofiev met Lunacharsky and asked permission to go abroad for a while. For Lunacharsky Prokofiev was 'a revolutionary in music as we are in life: we ought to work together'. Nevertheless he granted permission, sure that Prokofiev would return. After Japan, Prokofiev went to New York. Neon lights. Solo piano music. At first people were very interested in a Bolshevik composer. Quotes from critics superimposed in Cyrillic: 'A titan of the piano'; 'Steel fingers'; 'A carnival of cacophonies'. But interest died. Superimposed image of Prokofiev stood on the street. His best music was warmed by homesickness as in 'Tales of an Old Grandmother' (on the soundtrack). Panoramic views of various cities including Paris. SEGMENT 5: Stage curtains on the ballet 'The Jester Who Out-jested Seven Jesters' (also called 'Chout'), with jerky comic choreography. The Eiffel Tower and the Seine at sunset. Prokofiev's music was in danger of becoming disfigured by eccentricity and grotesquerie though this was popular with the bourgeoisie. Yet he was not happy. Birch trees and autumnal gardens, one of the Five Melodies on the soundtrack. Prokofiev becomes increasingly homesick and decides to return. Winter landscapes. Second Violin Concerto (adagio) on the soundtrack. His music became happy and radiant. Spring blossom. SEGMENT 6: Drawing of Prokofiev at work. He realises the need to write simpler music but in a new way. Soundtrack: 'Romeo and Juliet'. Prokofiev's house in Polenovo. Clips from Arnshtam's film of the ballet (1955): Juliet (Galina Ulanova) is chased by her nurse (I. Olenina). Juliet dances with a masked Romeo (Yuri Zhdanov), his mask falls and they see that they are members of opposing families. Having fallen in love, they dance together. Prokofiev's house. A truly national artist is invariably an internationalist. A book with Shakespeare's name in Cyrillic on the cover. SEGMENT 7: At this time Prokofiev wrote many works for children including 'Peter and the Wolf'. An audience of children. A woman introduces a performance (conducted by Gennadi Rozhdestvensky), explaining that each character is impersonated by a different instrument: the bird by a flute, the duck by an oboe, the cat by a clarinet, the grandfather by a bassoon, the wolf by three French horns, Peter by the strings, the hunters' shots by drums. Clips from Alexander Rau's 1960 film version of Prokofiev's ballet 'Cinderella' 'Khrustalnyi bashmachok Zolushka'. Midnight strikes and the clock's numbers dance around Cinderella. The prince dances with Cinderella. More of the midnight scene. The prince finds the slipper. But life brings greater dangers than fairy tale wizards. SEGMENT 8: 1938. Sunset. The clouds of war were closing in all over the world. Prokofiev met film director Sergei Eisenstein. Footage of Eisenstein leaning on a piano, leafing through photographs while Prokofiev plays. They worked together on the film 'Alexander Nevsky' about the 13th-century prince. Shots of the area where the film was made: churches, snowy landscapes. Clips from the film's Battle on the Ice superimposed over the modern landscape with Prokofiev's music, culminating in the heavily armoured Teutonic knights breaking the ice of the lake and sinking beneath the water. Clips from victory scenes with fire superimposed. The narrator draws a parallel between Nevsky and the Nazi invasion of the Soviet Union in 1941; two Russian victories. Tolstoy's novel 'War and Peace' upon which Prokofiev wrote an opera 'which would be recognised as the acme of his musical genius' [it was not performed as he wished during his lifetime]. Paintings of the 1812 campaign superimposed over the turning pages of the score. SEGMENT 9: Scenes from the opera 'War and Peace'. At a ball Natasha (played by Galina Vishnevskaya) dances and talks with Prince Andrei Bolkonsky. On the battlefield he talks about defending Russia. In his quarters General Kutuzov sings about the war with France. SEGMENT 10: The people won in both of patriotic wars, the first and the second. Fireworks. Gennadi Rozhdestvensky conducts the first movement of the Fifth Symphony: shots of players, the audience, and fireworks over the Kremlin. This was the last work Prokofiev conducted. Prokofiev moved to the country outside Moscow to live at Nikolina Gora. Shots of the countryside. Levitan, Chekhov and Taneyev had lived there. Prokofiev's friend Nikolai Miaskovsky also moved there. The house and woodland scenes. Prokofiev went for walks but increasing illness shortened them. He was visited by friends such as composers Kabalevsky, Shostakovich, Khachaturian, conductor Samosud and cellist Rostropovich. Soundtrack: Cello Sonata. SEGMENT 11: Photograph of Prokofiev. He continues to compose new pieces and revise older works. Violinist David Oistrakh and pianist Lev Oborin play the First Violin Sonata. Photograph of Prokofiev and Rostropovich who helped Prokofiev write a stupendous and forceful Cello Concerto. Rostropovich plays an excerpt accompanied by piano. Prokofiev's wicker rocking chair in his house. Landscapes. Prokofiev drew inspiration from everything around him. Combine harvesters on a wheat field. A large factory. He composed the cantata 'On Guard for Peace' (on the soundtrack) to express the assurance that war would not break out again. Children in a classroom. On the blackboard a child writes 'We do not need war'. Another repeats it in an exercise book. Children from all over the world. SEGMENT 12: Prokofiev's house: the piano. He struggled against illness. He enjoyed playing chess but had to give it up (a chess board disappears from the scene). He could no longer use the telephone (the phone disappears). He was not allowed to play the piano (the lid closes) but he continued to compose: for him composing was the same as living. Animated section of music appearing on the page. His next opera was 'The Story of Real Man' about a Soviet airman who is crippled but learns how to fly again. Excerpts. Immediately after his crash, Alexei lies on the ground but rejoices that he is still alive. He gets up but falls to the ground and struggles home. SEGMENT 13: In hospital Alexei is frustrated by his injuries but is consoled by a friend and remembers that he is a Soviet man, just as Prokofiev struggled against his illness. At a local dance Alexei demonstrates that he is fit to fly again by dancing with a woman. In a birch copse he sings. A montage of Prokofiev's scores. He completed over 300 works. His swansong was his Seventh Symphony which won a Lenin Prize [sic. it actually won a Stalin Prize]. The leather folder in which Lenin Prizes are distributed, with a cameo of Lenin on the cover. Gennadi Rozhdestvensky conducts it. The narrator compares the melody to a lovely swan. Pan over scores and recordings of Prokofiev's works. A photo of him. His music will live on in the grateful hearts of the people.

SECONDARY_AUTHORS.SECONDARY_AUTHOR: Including Vladimir Ashkenazy, Noelle Mann and David Nice

RECORD.NOTES: Programme (taken from playlist): REMAINS OF THE DAY: Berlioz's 200th anniversary has sparked a row over his final resting place. His fans are divided over whether his remains should be moved to the Panthéon in Paris. Hugh Schofield reports. GREAT PERFORMER: Dermot Clinch talks to pianist Murray Perahia. CRYING WOLF: To mark the hundredth anniversary of the death of Hugo Wolf, Dermot Clinch asks Susan Youens, Joan Rodgers, Rodger Vignoles and Christa Ludvig whether Wolf was the greatest lieder composer of all. PROKOFIEV ON TRIAL: This week marks the 50th anniversary of the death of Sergei Prokofiev. From Moscow, Nicholas Walton traces the life of the man. And Tommy Pearson talks to pianist and conductor Vladimir Ashkenavy, curator of the Prokofiev Archive Noëlle Mann and biographer David Nice about the impact of Stalinism on Prokofiev's music

RECORD.TITLE: S. Prokofiev (dir. Lidia Stepanova); archival footage
RECORD.NOTES: 1. Composer S. Prokofiev (dir. Lidia Stepanova) 2 i) "Kompozitor S. Prokof'eva, vozvrativshiisia v SSSR" [silent film of Prokofiev playing with Persimfans, 1927]. ii) Prize giving ceremony with Prokofiev, Khachaturian, Shebalin etc. (silent) iii) Prokofiev at his dacha in 1946. Plays an extract from the Waltz Suite and is then interviewed (with sound). Brief clip of Shostakovich iv) Performance of Piano Concerto No. 3; unidentified pianist and orchestra, conductor Kirill Kondrashin v) Section on Eisenstein. Shows plans and drawings for Ivan Grozny and a scene with Prokofiev at the piano
